results.title: Keith the wombat
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Wild Life”.
This film teaches the habits and characteristics of a wombat for the younger child by showing a day’s activity in the life of an animal kept as a pet. The animal is shown being bathed, fed, rubbing itself in a hollow log and swimming. A young wombat is shown just taken from the mother’s pouch.

results.title: The Koala, or 'native bear'
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Wild Life”.
Koala in Aboriginal = “no drink”. Koala in science = phascolarctos/pouched bear. Describes the stages in the early life of a koala, its characteristics, habitations, and comments on the pecularities of its diet.
results.description:

results.title: The Southern edge: marsh and mangroves
results.creator_credit: Michael Vance, Robert Horne and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Shows the dependence of Westernport Bay on the fringing salt-marsh and mangroves. We see the organisms of these vegetations in their natural surroundings and in the laboratory. Illustrates the density and diversity of the wildlife, and the changes along a transect from saltmarsh to sea. Narrated by Ross Thompson and introduced by Charles McCubbin.

results.title: To the island (Macquarie Island)
results.creator_credit: Ken Taylor, Robert Horne and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Examines the wildlife on sub-Antarctic Macquarie Island, including seals, penguins, skuas, petrels, cape pigeons etc. Culminates in closeup views of the light-mantled sooty albatross and the synchronous courtship flight of a pair of these birds.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.

results.title: Across the Strait
results.creator_credit: Ken Taylor, Robert Horne and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
The Cape Barren goose one of the world’s rarest species, is found on the island in Bass Strait. Looks at the birds in their natural environment and describes their varying fortunes at the hands of man. Other birds filmed include Pacific gulls, cormorants, black swans, the chestnut teal and the spur-winged plover also emphasising research by Dr. Dorward on Glennie Island.

results.title: Against the escarpment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
A view of wildlife, mainly birds, in natural surroundings in Arnhem Land. Includes a discussion of threats to the ecological balance. Birds shown include the black banded pigeon, brolga, ibis, pygmy and magpie geese

results.title: The Seal watch with Bob Warneke
results.creator_credit: Ken Taylor, Robert Horne and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
This film, taken at the height of the breeding season of the seals in the Bass Strait, records the annual out-haul of the 800 lb weight territorial males and their violent battles for breeding territory. Included is the birth of a seal pup and a description of the challenges to its survival. Cinematography by Keith Taylor.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.

results.title: The Diminishing rain forest
results.creator_credit: Ken Taylor, Robert Horne and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Shows the wildlife in an Australian tropical forest and how it survives natural devastation but not the influence of man. Contains footage of John Olsen paintings. Commentary by Douglas Dorward.
